Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Climatic Niche Evolution in South American Trees and its Consequences
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This fellowship funds Dr. Kyle Dexter to spend 24 months conducting research with Dr. Oliver Phillips, of Leeds University, and Dr. Toby Pennington, of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.

The focus of the project is to investigate the evolution of climatic niches through time in South American trees. The 3-way collaboration takes advantage of several existing large-scale networks of tree plots in diverse climatic zones of South America, the ecological expertise of Dr. Phillips, the phylogenetic expertise of Dr. Pennington, and the expertise of Dr. Dexter in integrating ecological and phylogenetic approaches. More specifically, the research plan is to synthesize taxonomy across the plot networks, which are found in different climatic biomes (e.g. rainforest, dry forest, savannah), and to then construct phylogenies, or evolutionary trees, for all genera of angiosperms and all species of the Leguminosae present in the plot networks. This will allow the investigators to examine how evolutionary lineages, be they families, genera, or species, have shifted among climatic biomes through time.

This project will elucidate the role of climatic preference switching in driving speciation of trees and give insights into the future of South American forests under climate change. For example, the investigators will be able to assess which lineages are more vulnerable under alternative future climatic scenarios and how much evolutionary history may be lost if specific climatic biomes disappear.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regarding Intellectual Merit, I have published 11 articles in various journals (see below) during my tenure as an International Research Fellowship. Much of this was based on research done previously, but the fellowship allowed me time to properly write up the publications. I currently have two additional publications in revision and two in review as well as many more on the way. These are based largely on the work I completed during my time as a fellow. I have also given talks at numerous international conferences and various universities and research institutions. More broadly speaking, the research I proposed to do during the fellowship is ongoing. While much has been accomplished, there is much left to do. The latter is possible because the preliminary results obtained from the fellowship funding have allowed myself and colleagues to secure a NERC Standard Grant from the UK government to continue research on the theme. So far, we have succeeded in standardizing taxonomic identifications across a network of 300+ tree plots in the Amazon basin. We have also already obtained DNA sequences for most of the genera occurring in these plots as well as many of the species in the family Leguminosae. These datasets will allow us to address fundamental ecological and evolutionary questions with an unprecedented spatial and phylogenetic scale.

 

Beyond the core research outputs, I spent part of the fellowship tenure revamping the forestplots.net database. This is an online database that brings together plot data from across the tropics (South America, Africa, Asia, and Australia). We standardized taxonomic names for all plots in South America. Further, we have created a user-friendly interface that allows anyone to readily download plot data, and we incorporated high-resolution photographs of specimens from trees from most of the plots in South America. These two features promise to greatly help anyone setting up plots in tropical regions in doing taxonomic determinations of trees in their plots.

 

In addition, during the fellowship tenure, I contributed to increasing the representation of underrepresented groups via training of multiple M.Sc. and Ph.D. students and colleagues from Latin America in fundamental scientific skills such as field ecology and botany, statistical analysis, and scientific writing. Lastly, I have worked on outreach by contributing to the development of an exhibit on my and colleague’s research at the Visitor Centre of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh (scheduled for 2014).
